abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, the Bank performance was highly satisfactory,
            and the borrower performance was satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that any novel technology and IT software
            being introduced by a project of this type should take into
            account the ground conditions, the capacity for absorption
            by the users and therefore appropriate training and phasing
            needs to be part of the project design. Hydrology Project
            (HP) design did not include data-related, value-addition
            studies as part of its MIS/learning environment. Practical
            application and use of HIS should be further strengthened by
            introducing Decision Support Systems for water related
            operations. Any project of this recurring nature needs
            understanding and firm support of the high level management
            for success of project implementation and its
            sustainability. There is a need to develop a project
            planning and monitoring mechanism suited to Indian
            conditions as externally developed Hydrology Institutional
            Development Action Plan (HIDAP) has proven ill-suited due to
            an insufficient recognition/ incorporation of institutional
            settings and culture in India. At Project closure, it
            appears that the use of HIS data remains opportunistic and
            meetings of data user groups (HDUG) have mostly served as a
            means of informing potential users about Hydrological
            Information System (HIS) rather than exploring, in a dynamic
            and participatory manner, feedback for improved HIS management.
